article:
A 'line echo wave pattern' or 'LEWP' (pronounced "loop" or spelled out) is the
radar signature associated with a multiple-bow serial derecho.

A LEWP, according to the NWAS, is defined as "a squall line that has developed
into a wave-like pattern due to acceleration at one end of the line and
deceleration along the portion immediately adjacent."

A LEWP can be compared to the bow echo, which usually indicates a powerful
convective windstorm. Areas hit by the apices of bows often see the worst
weather, with the highest winds and very heavy rain. However, if the sides of
the bows reach enough of an orientation parallel to the derecho's movement, a
very long-duration heavy rain event can result, leading to flash flooding. A
serial derecho can be in the form of a LEWP or a single, very large bow
echo.

LEWP events can produce strong, damaging winds and tornadoes.
